anchor.surface_text: Article 246 of the Constitution lays down the principle that the Parliament alone has exclusive powers to make laws with respect to any of the matters enumerated in List I of the Seventh Schedule. holdings.text: Natural Gas including Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) is a Union subject covered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative competence to enact laws on natural gas.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Reference is answered in the following terms Q. 1. Whether Natural Gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of the List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact. I. Natural Gas including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact laws on natural gas.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislative history, statutory definitions treating natural gas as petroleum/mineral oil, uniform practice, national interest in equitable distribution across states.

holdings.text: The States have no legislative competence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Q.2. Whether States have legislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. A.2. The States have numberlegislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 25 read with 'gas works' covers only manufactured gas; natural gas excluded by specific Union entry 53 and harmonious construction.

holdings.text: The Gujarat Gas Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution Act, 2001, so far as the provisions contained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas (LNG) are concerned, is without any legislative competence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: Q.3. Whether the State of Gujarat had legislative companypetence to enact the Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001. A.3. The Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001, so far as the provisions companytained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas  LNG  are companycerned, is without any legislative companypetence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State lacks competence on natural gas under Entry 25; Act's definition includes natural gas, trenching on Union field.

holdings.text: Under Entry 25 List II of the Seventh Schedule, the State would be competent to pass a legislation only in respect of gas and gas-works... this Entry would mean any work or industry relating to manufactured gas.

anchor.surface_text: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd v. State of West Bengal and Ors., 1962 Suppl. 3 SCR I, the scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II had been authoritatively pronounced by this Court and this Court held that the field of entire industry, dealing with gas and gas works would fall under Entry 25 of List II.

precedents.cited_proposition: scope and ambit of Entry 25 of List II covers the field of entire industry dealing with gas and gas works

anchor.surface_text: Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay. 1939 3 FLJ HC 25 at 31, that the Courts must, if possible, reconcile conflicting items in the Central and Provincial Lists before falling back to the notwithstanding clause in Section 100 of the Government of India Act,

precedents.case_name: Sir Byramji Jeejibhai v. Province of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: Courts must reconcile conflicting items in Central and Provincial Lists and may restrict general words of Federal list to preserve Provincial power

anchor.surface_text: In re The Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938 1939 ELR 18 at page 42-44 observed A grant of the power in general terms, standing by itself, would no doubt be construed in the wider sense, but it may be qualified by other express provisions in the same enactment,

precedents.case_name: In re Central Provinces and Berar Act No. XIV of 1938
precedents.cited_proposition: reconciliation of apparently conflicting legislative entries by reference to context and scheme, federal power prevails only if irreconcilable
precedents.cited_holding: A grant of the power in general terms... qualified by... context... endeavour must be made... reconciliation attempted...

precedents.cited_proposition: pith and substance doctrine for determining legislative competence when laws overlap lists

precedents.citation: Subramanyan Chettiar v. Muttitswami Goundar, 1940 FCR 188

anchor.surface_text: Subramanyan Chettiar v. Muttitswami Goundar, 1940 FCR 188 were quoted with approval It must inevitably happen from time to time that legislation, though purporting to deal with a subject in one list, touches also on a subject in another list,

precedents.cited_proposition: legislation purporting to deal with one list may touch another; examine pith and substance

precedents.citation: Borys vs. Canadian Pacific Railway Co. and Anr., 1953 1 All ER 451

anchor.surface_text: Borys vs. Canadian Pacific Railway Co. and Anr., 1953 1 All ER 451 and contended that gas and petroleum are two distinct commodities. That was a case where the appellant owned an estate in Alberta.

precedents.case_name: Borys v. Canadian Pacific Railway Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: gas and petroleum are distinct commodities

precedents.citation: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co., 1959 SCR 379

anchor.surface_text: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co., 1959 SCR 379, it was observed that it is important to consider the legislative practice in interpreting the various words used in the Constitution.

precedents.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co.
precedents.cited_proposition: weight to be given to legislative practice in interpreting constitutional words

anchor.surface_text: Croft v. Dumphy, 1933 AC 156, the question was as to the validity of certain provisions in a Canadian statute providing for the search of vessels beyond territorial waters.

precedents.cited_proposition: regard to legislative practice in determining scope of power

precedents.citation: Walace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District

anchor.surface_text: Walace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City and Bombay Suburban District, Lord Uthwatt observed Where Parliament has conferred a power to legislate on a particular topic it is permissible and important in determining the scope and meaning of the power to have regard to what is ordinarily treated as embraced within that topic in the legislative practice of the United Kingdom.

precedents.case_name: Wallace Bros. & Co. Ltd. v. CIT, Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: regard to legislative practice of the conferring state in interpreting power

precedents.citation: In Re Cauvery Water Dispute Tribunal, 1993 Supp.l SCC 96

precedents.case_name: In re Cauvery Water Disputes Tribunal
precedents.cited_proposition: natural resources like river water are of national interest (publici juris)

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the Reference is answered in the following terms Q. 1. Whether Natural Gas in whatever physical form including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of the List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact. I. Natural Gas including Liquefied Natural Gas  LNG  is a Union subject companyered by Entry 53 of List I and the Union has exclusive legislative companypetence to enact laws on natural gas.
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

Q.2. Whether States have legislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution. A.2. The States have numberlegislative companypetence to make laws on the subject of natural gas and liquefied natural gas under Entry 25 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.

edges.explanation: The holding specifies that provisions of the Gujarat Gas Act relating to natural gas and LNG are ultra vires, directly addressing the issue of the state's legislative competence to enact the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Q.3. Whether the State of Gujarat had legislative companypetence to enact the Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001. A.3. The Gujarat Gas  Regulation of Transmission, Supply Distribution  Act, 2001, so far as the provisions companytained therein relating to the natural gas or liquefied natural gas  LNG  are companycerned, is without any legislative companypetence and the Act is to that extent ultra vires of the Constitution.
ORDER In the light of the opinion rendered in Special Reference No. 1/2001 under Article 143 1  of the Constitution of India, the Writ Petition and the Civil Appeals are dismissed.
